sourcesContent: import React from 'react' import { Grid, Typography, Card, IconButton } from '@mui/material' import { useNavigate } from 'react-router-dom'; import ArrowBackIcon from '@mui/icons-material/ArrowBack' const classes = { container: { display: 'flex', flexDirection: 'column', justifyContent: 'center', alignItems: 'center', minWidth: '100vw', minHeight: '100vh', backgroundColor: '#3f3f3f' }, myCard: { maxWidth: '90vw', minHeight: '100vh', position: 'relative', flexDirection: 'column', justifyContent: 'center', alignItems: 'center', background: 'linear-gradient(to bottom, #F7F61B, #168820)', padding: 3, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { fontSize: '1.5rem', padding: 1 }, }, myQuestion: { minWidth: '30vw', minHeight: '100vh', display: 'flex', position: 'left', padding: 3, flexDirection: 'column', background: "radial-gradient(circle, rgba(255,255,255,1) 0%, rgba(66,181,129,1) 100%)" }, myTitle: { fontSize: '1.8rem', opacity: '0.8', fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', marginLeft: 5, padding: 1, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { marginLeft: 0, textAlign: 'center', fontSize: '1.5rem', }, }, myLabels: { fontSize: '1.5rem', opacity: '0.8', marginLeft: 5, fontWeight: 'bold', fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', padding: 1, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { marginLeft: 0, fontSize: '1.2rem', }, }, myTimeText: { fontSize: '1.2rem', fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', "@media (max-width: 600px)": { fontSize: '1rem' }, }, myImg: { display: 'flex', padding: 10, "@media (max-width: 600px)": { padding: 2, }, }, myText: { fontSize: '1.2rem', paddingTop: 0, paddingLeft: 10, paddingBottom: 5, paddingRight: 10, fontFamily: 'Varela Round', color: 'black', "@media (max-width: 600px)": { marginLeft: 0, fontSize: '1rem', paddingTop: 0, paddingLeft: 2, paddingBottom: 0, paddingRight: 2, }, }, myIcon: { width: '5vw', minHeight: '5vh', } } export default function EXTERNAL_FEATURES() { const navigate = useNavigate(); const handleBack = () => { navigate('/main/explore/') }; return ( G. FROG EXTERNAL FEATURES AND MOUTH CAVITY 1. EXTERNAL ANATOMY Axial Region a.) Head  i. snout - protruding region of the head ending; anterior to the eyes in a more or less triangular border.  ii. external nares (nostrils) – two small openings near the tip of the snout.  iii. eyes – found at the dorso-lateral portion of the head; these protected by the upper eyelids, lower eyelids, and the transparent third eyelid called nictitating membrane.  iv. tympanic membrane (eardrum) – away from the place of attachment; toward the periphery of extremities of the body; opposite of proximal. b.) trunk The trunk is divisible into two regions:  i. thoracic or chest region – the anterior half; located in this region of the toad, in the poison or parotoid glands, which are elevated structures of the skin just behind the tympanum. These glands are absent in frogs.  ii. abdominal or lumbar region – the posterior half; the ventral portion is the abdominal region, and the dorsal is the lumbar region.  iii. sacral hump – marked elevation of the mid-dorsal surface of the trunk near the posterior end; located at the posterior end of the pelvic girdle; very evident in frogs and not in toads. Appendicular Region a.) Forelimbs - the two forward appendages; at anterior end of the trunk; each consists of:  i. upper arm - the first segment attached to the trunk.  ii. middle forearm – next segment immediately below the forearm.  iii. carpus or wrist – next to the forearm  iv. manus or hand – distal to the wrist.  v. fingers – four digits; the inner digit (thumb) is swollen in males.  vi. pre-pollux – rudimentary first finger; can be felt on the inner side of the hand as a short stump. b.) Hindlimbs - the two posterior appendages; divided into segments as follows:  i. thigh - the first segment attached to the body mass.  ii. shank – or lower leg; next segment below thigh.  iii. tarsus or ankle – next segment immediately below the shank.  iv. pes or foot – the distal end below tarsus.  v. toes or digits – these are five in number.  vi. pre-hallux – a degenerated digit on the inner side of the foot; supposed to be the 6th toe.  vii. web – a membranous extension of the skin connecting one toe to the other; present only in frog but not in toad. 2. MOUTH CAVITY  i. vomerine teeth - two small batches of fine teeth between the internal nares projecting from the vomer bones; absent in toads.  ii. maxillary teeth – row of small conical teeth on the margin of the upper jaw; absent in toads.  iii. internal nares – two anterior openings in the roof of the mouth; these open dorsally as external nares.  iv. Eustachian tube openings – two at the corner of the mouth near the roof of the oral cavity; each connects to middle ear.  v. tongue – large and long bilobes structure occupying a great part of the floor of the oral cavity.  vi. pharynx – most posterior part of the mouth cavity.  vii. vocal sac openings – , lateral in the floor of mouth; present in males.  viii. glottis – a narrow longitudinal slit in the floor of the pharynx; an opening of the larynx or voice box into the mouth cavity.  ix. esophagus – the posterior opening in the pharynx that leads to the stomach.  x. hyoid cartilage – the supportive element of the tongue; can be located by probing the floor of the mouth below the tongue. ) }
